engineering and plant management.

Two key areas for employee participation include the Employee Behavioral Safety Process (RAPTOR) and the Employee EHS Excellence Team.

Process Safety Information
Sweeny/Old Ocean maintains a variety of technical documents that are used in the safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration
information. Specific departments within Sweeny/Old Ocean are assigned responsibility for maintaining upto-date Process Safety Information. Process Safety Information reference documents are readily available as part of the written Employee Participation Plan to help employees locate any necessary Process Safety Information.Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). For specific process areas, Sweeny/Old Ocean has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition) in the unit-specific Process Safety Information (PSI) document. The teams verify the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).

Sweeny/Old Ocean also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in
combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to confirm the s

documented
for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

Contractors
Sweeny/Old Ocean uses contractors as part of its regular work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to verify that contractors (1) perform their work in a
safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, (6) inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.
This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a Process Overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) Emergency Response Plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, Sweeny/Old Ocean evaluates contractor safety programs and
performance during the selection of the contractor. Plant personnel periodically conduct audits of contractor performance to help ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. Contractors regularly participate in facility emergency drills.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR's)
Sweeny/Old Ocean conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to confirm that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the
equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make certain construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field
verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification

Executive Summary (2017)
Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP
Sweeny/Old Ocean
Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP Sweeny/Old Ocean has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training and consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous chemicals. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain release. 

Continuous improvement in safety and environmental performance will be achieved, among other things, through the company's Employee Safety Process, Tenets of Operation, guiding principles, and RAPTOR (Revealing At Risk Potentials Through Observing and Reporting) Program. Planned changes to improve safety are reviewed and adjusted annually. They are also included in the yearly budgets; and incorporated into the performance management systems/practice throughout the organization. These planned changes include, but are not limited to, safety related capital projects,
safety programs/initiatives, procedure improvements, and SOP validations.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP Sweeny/Old Ocean consists of six covered processes linked by multiple pipelines. The complex, near Old Ocean, Texas, is at the intersection of State Highway 35 and FM 524, about 60 miles southwest of downtown Houston. Sweeny/Old Ocean also operates a terminal
and storage facility, along with the pipelines that connect this facility to the main plant and its markets. The plant produces simple olefins, including ethylene and propylene, some C6 products, butadiene, and Natural Gas Liquids (NGL). These products are primarily intermediates which our
customers

use to produce finished consumer products such as plastics and packaging, biodegradable detergents, synthetic lubricants, and hydraulic fluids, and waxes. Sweeny/Old Ocean produces 4.1 billion pounds of ethylene and 2.2 billion pounds of polyethylene per year. In our process, we use the following chemicals the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a
substantial accidental release:

Toxics: None

Flammables: Normal Butane, Ethylene, Propane, Ethane, 2-Butene-trans, 1-Butene, 2Butene-cis, Butene, Isobutane, 2-Butene, Hydrogen, Isopentane, Methane, Pentane, 1,3-Butadiene, Propylene, Isoprene, 1-Pentene, Propadiene, 1,3-Propadiene, 2-Pentene.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps
The following is a summary of the General Accidental Release Prevention Program in place at the Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP Sweeny/Old Ocean. Because processes at the plant regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management
(PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the Accidental Release Prevention Program.

Employee Participation
Sweeny/Old Ocean management encourages employees to participate in all facets of risk management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a Process
Hazard Analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the Sweeny/Old Ocean's Accidental Release Prevention Program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the Accidental Release Prevention Program are documented in the Employee
Participation Element of the Sweeny/Old Ocean Process Safety Management System. In addition, Sweeny/Old Ocean has a number of teams to promote both process safety and personal safety. The teams typically in

all aspects of emergency response, including the following: proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures; evacuation plans and accounting for personnel
after an evacuation; notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occur; and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, Sweeny/Old Ocean has procedures that address maintenance inspection, and testing of emergency response
equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.

A full time firefighter/paramedic, along with fully trained volunteer responders, covers all four rotating shifts to ensure 24-hour coverage and protection. These personnel report to the on-site fire station in the event of an emergency. This fire station is equipped with various apparatus to allow it to address various emergencies in a safe and effective manner.

Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The Emergency Response Program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant processes or other plant facilities.

The overall Emergency Response Program for Sweeny/Old Ocean is coordinated with the Brazoria County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes: local emergency response officials, local government officials, and
industry representatives. Sweeny/Old Ocean has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, Sweeny/Old Ocean conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the
LEPC and emergency response organizations. In addition to the LEPC, Sweeny/Old Ocean also has a Mutual Aid System in place. The Emerg

that Accidental Release Prevention Program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
Sweeny/Old Ocean has well established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, control, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) Equipment
Identification and categorization, (2) conducting training, (3) developing written procedures, (4) performing inspections, tests and preventive maintenance, (5) correcting identified deficiencies, and (6) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that
maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. 

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) Emergency Response Plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures confirm work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to verify equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or an cross functional Team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment. 

Another integral part of the Mechanical Integrity Program is quality assurance. Sweeny/Old Ocean
incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure
that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are
used when repairs are made.

Safe Work Practices
Sweeny/Old Ocean has long-standing safe work pr

actices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel (B.17), (2) a Lockout/Tagout Procedure (B.6) to verify isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) procedures for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened (B.20), (4) a permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e., hot work, B.1), (5) a permit and procedure to confirm adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space (B.2), and (6) a Safety and Emergency Systems Bypass Permit procedure(C.4). These procedures and others, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change
Sweeny/Old Ocean has a comprehensive system to manage change that utilizes both a written site procedure, PSM-1100 Management of Change and Pre-startup safety Review, as well as a company-wide software system. This software system aids in managing changes and provides a mean of controlling the change process through required safety and health evaluation, appropriate approval, and pre-startup safety review steps. This system requires that change to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes to be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) verify adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.

Incident Investigation
Sweeny/Old Ocean promptly investigates all incidents tha

afety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis
Sweeny/Old Ocean has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and verify that adequate controls are in place to manage these
hazards.

Sweeny/Old Ocean primarily uses the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. The team employs a Layer of Protection Analysis(LOPA) to assist with this task.

The PHA Team findings are forwarded to local and corporate management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA Team (using LOPA). This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA Team findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

To confirm that process controls and/or process hazards do not deviate significantly from the original design features Sweeny/Old Ocean periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and

t result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the Root Cause and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent recurrence, and forwards these results to plant management and respective Teams for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the
investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until these actions have been resolved. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected
by these findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years in order for these reports to be available for review during future PHA's and PHA revalidations. Guidance on incident investigations is provided through site procedure A.2 Incident Investigation.

Compliance Audits
Sweeny/Old Ocean periodically conducts compliance audits that include the following: Internal PSM and RMP Audits, Designated Self Audits (Safety and Health), and Operational Excellence (OE) Audit (which contains all elements of Responsible Care Evaluations). Audit teams comprised of both
hourly and management personnel conduct these audits. Audits for compliance with both the PSM and RMP regulatory requirements are conducted at least every three years according to the corporate auditing protocol. Some audits or evaluations of individual process safety elements may be conducted in the intervening years according to a specific need for that area. Audit findings are developed and presented to management for resolution. All responses to audit findings are tracked until resolution. All audits are retained for at least 5 years.

Risk Management Process
In addition to the OSHA

the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.

Operating Procedures
Sweeny/Old Ocean maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as: (1) Unit startup, (2) Normal operations, (3) Temporary operations, (4) Emergency shutdown, (5) Normal shutdown, and (6) Initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to
reflect changes made through the Management of Change process.

In addition, Sweeny/Old Ocean maintains a Process Safety Information document that provides guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit exceedances for specific process or equipment parameters. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.

Training
To complement the written procedures for process operations, Sweeny/Old Ocean has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. Training for process operators is managed by the plant Training Department and includes rigorous initial hire or
job transfer training with classroom and on-the-job elements. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process specific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) that they have adequate
knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to confirm their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. All of this training is

ency Assistance Agreement Committee (EAAC) is a sub-committee of the Industrial CAER organization in the Brazosport area. This system provides
Mutual Aid from other industry members in the Brazosport area. In addition, the Local Volunteer Fire Departments and West Brazos Emergency Medical Service would provide assistance in the event of an emergency at Sweeny/Old Ocean. The EAAC conducts emergency drills quarterly each year,
hosted by a facility with the other member facilities participating.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
As part of the Sweeny/Old Ocean commitment to continuously improving the safety of our processes, some of the initiatives and measures that have been taken or are on-going include:
1. Ongoing Facility Siting and Spacing Analysis based on OSHA and API RP guidelines to determine the risk to building occupants from external explosion, fire, or toxic release and develop a plan
2. Adding Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) to the processes which meet ANSI/ISA-84.01-1996 and IEC 61511 standards requirements as determined by Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) and Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA) reviews.
3. To monitor the overall effectiveness of the facility's PSM programs, Process Safety Metrics are generated routinely and reviewed with all units, departments, and the Leadership Team.
4. Plant equipment is being assessed for possible Corrosion Under Insulation (CUI) and corrective and preventative measures are being taken to address this potential hazard when necessary.
5. Relief Valve and Relief Header Analysis and Re-engineering
6. EHS Excellence Team Activities
7. Specialized Safety Training
8. Environmental Awareness Training

PERMITS, EXEMPTIONS AND GENERAL INFORMATION

TCEQ Flexible Permit 22690/PSD-TX-751M1 (Amendment 03/08/2012)

PSM elements described above, Sweeny/Old Ocean incorporates the elements of Chevron Phillips' Operational Excellence Program in the Safety and Health process of the facility. The elements of this management process include the following:

Responsible Care (Codes of Management Practice)
(1) Leadership, Commitment, and Responsibility
(2) Training
(3) Community Awareness and Outreach
(4) Emergency Response and Preparedness
(5) Pollution Prevention and Resource Conservation
(6) Process Safety
(7) Distribution
(8) Employee Health and Safety
(9) Product Stewardship
(10) Regulatory Assessment and Advocacy
(11) Compliance Assurance and Reviews

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The processes at Sweeny/Old Ocean have hazards that must be managed to help ensure continued safe operation. The Accidental Release Prevention Program summarized previously is applicable to all EPA RMP covered processes at the facility. Collectively, these prevention program activities help
prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors. In addition to the Accidental Release Prevention Program activities, Sweeny/Old Ocean has safety features on many processes to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release , and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

(1) Release Detection
(2) Gas Detectors (Hydrocarbon) with Alarms
(3) Release Containment/Control
(4) Process Relief Valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
(5) Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated)
(6) Automated Shutdown Systems for specific process parameters (e.g., High level, high
temperature, release detection)
(7) Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control
system, backup firewater pump)
(8) Atmospheric Relief Devices
(9) Structural/Equipment Fi

re Proofing
(10) Relief Valve Maintenance Procedures
(11) Release Mitigation
(12) Fire Suppression and Extinguishing Systems
(13) Deluge System for specific equipment
(14) Trained Emergency Response Personnel
(15) Personal Protective Equipment(e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
(16) Control Building is located outside of potential release areas
(17) Water curtains for specific equipment
(18) Siting and Spacing Initiative
(19) Emergency Isolation Valves
(20) Emergency Activation System
(21) Risk Based Inspection

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been two (2) accidents with on-site effects in the last five years involving chemicals that are on the 40 CFR PART 68.130 List of Substances and meeting the RMP criteria for five-year accidents.

One accident was a fire which involved ethane and propane and resulted in direct costs of $7.9 million. No one on or off site was injured as a result of the fire.

The other accident was a fire which involved ethylene and resulted in direct costs of $5.3 million. No one on or off site was injured as a result of the fire. 

There have been zero (0) accidents with off-site effects in the last five years involving chemicals that are on the 40 CFR PART 68.130 List of Substances and meeting the RMP criteria for accidents.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
Sweeny/Old Ocean has an internal plant wide alarm system for fires and emergencies. In addition, the Old Ocean community alarm system can be activated in the event of incidents with potential offsite consequences.

Sweeny/Old Ocean maintains a written Emergency Response Program called the Integrated Contingency Plan or the One Plan which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated
substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address
